title: 114_hr3442
content: The Act titled "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt reaches the specified limit. The report must include details on the public debt, Federal revenue levels, and future debt projections. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on the public debt levels, revenue, future projections, debt obligations, and reduction measures if the debt limit is not raised. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on public debt levels, revenue, future projections, debt obligations, and reduction measures if the debt limit is not raised. The President may recommend a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation and must provide detailed proposals to reduce public debt in the short, medium, and long term, as well as adjust the debt-to-GDP ratio. The curr_chunk discusses the impact of increasing the debt limit on government spending, debt service, and the position of the US dollar as the international reserve currency. It also includes projections on the fiscal health of major entitlement programs like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid. Additionally, it outlines the President's plan to publicly disclose reduction measures used to avoid defaulting on government obligations if the debt limit is reached. The curr_chunk provides details on reduction measures used by the Secretary of the Treasury to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including the total dollar amounts used and estimated amounts still available. It also includes the projected date when these measures will be exhausted, leading to a government default, and mentions any extraordinary measures the Secretary plans to take to fund federal government obligations. The curr_chunk outlines the Secretary of the Treasury's plans to avoid defaulting on government obligations, including projected exhaustion of reduction measures and potential extraordinary measures to fund federal obligations. It also addresses the Administration's technological capability to prioritize paying principal and interest on the national debt. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide a progress report on implementing the President's proposals to address the debt limit. Additionally, a webpage will be created to make information available to the public, including debt reports, detailed explanations, and progress reports. The Secretary of the Treasury will make information available to the public for at least 6 months after releasing debt reports, detailed explanations, and progress reports. Reduction measures include directing debt issuance, suspending investments in the Government Securities Investment Fund, and the stabilization fund. The Secretary of the Treasury may take various measures to reduce debt, such as suspending investments in different funds, selling assets before maturity, and implementing other appropriate actions. The House of Representatives passed a report on February 11, 2016, before reaching the debt limit. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
